I received charge of the prisoner at Mr. Bossard's house, I searched her, but found nothing on her—she told me she had wrapped the half-sovereing in a piece of paper, and given it to her mother, who lives about thirty yards from the prosecutor—I did not go to her present—they are poor people—I called on her mother yesterday, but she denied her name, and I could not find her—the father was in work at the time of the robbery, but has since gone into the country.

833.
JOHN DOUGLAS was indicted
for stealing 1 ring, value 7s. the goods of
Mary Ann Andrews—2nd COUNT, stealing it to be the goods of
Philip Andrews.

MARY ANN ANDREWS . I am the wife of Philip Andrews, of Red Lion-street, Richmond. I had a gold wedding-ring in a drawer in my house just before Christmas—I missed it, with other articles, on the 26th of Dec.—the prisoner was in the habit of coming to my house—I was out at work at the time the things were taken—I found the drawer locked, but the ring was gone—I do not know whether I left it locked—the key was in my pocket—I have not worn the ring—it fitted tight when I bought it, last summer, as my own was broken—I have no mark on it.

THOMAS BURFORD . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Old Brentford. On the 8th of Jan. the prisoner pawned this ring—he said he pawned it for his mother, Sarah Douglas, to pay her rent, whom I knew as his mother—he had often been at our shop with her.

WILLIAM FRENCH ANDREWS . I am the son of Mary Ann Andrews. The prisoner used to come to my mother's house when she was out—I used to go with him on the Green—I cannot say how soon before Christmas he came there.

Prisoner. You said to me, "I have got a ring; I do not know whether it is gold or not; will you go and see?" he said, "Take it over to Mr. Burford, and do not put it in your name, put it in my mother's name;" I bought him the money. Witness. It is false—I did not give it him—I did not know he had it.

STEPHEN CREED (police-Constable V 200.) In consequence of informa
tion, I went to Burford's, and found a ring answering the description given by Mr. Andrrews—I got a description of the boy who pawned it, went to the prisoner's house, took him, and told him the charge—he denied all knowledge of it—I took him to the station; and while being charged there, he said he had pawned the gold ring, but Bill Andrews gave it him—I examined the drawer—there was a mark of a chisel, or some blunt instrument, on it.
JURY. Q. Where was the drawer? A. Up stairs.

WILLIAM FRENCH ANDREWS
re-examined. The prisoner visited me in the bed-room—I suppose the ring was kept there—there was a chest of drawers there—the prisoner could have got to them without my seeing him—I was in bed asleep—he came and asked me if he should go down and light the fire—I said, "You may please yourself about that," and then I went off to sleep—I cannot say when it was, or how soon after that my mother missed the ring—he used often to come to the house.

MRS. ANDREWS re-examined. On 26th of Jan. when I missed the ring, I asked my son if he had had the prisoner up in the bed-room—he said he had—I came home one day, before the loss, and forbad the prisoner coming to the house.

GUILTY *(†) Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Year.

834.
EDWARD HIGGS
was indicated for stealing 1 pewter pot, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Thomas Wilkinson.

WILLIAM LEA (police-constable V 38.) On the 15th of Feb. about half-past six o'clock in the evening, I was watching, and saw the prisoner in Garrett-lane, Wandsworth—I saw a quart-pot hanging on a fence opposite Mr. Wilkinson's beer-shop—the prisoner stopped and looked at the quart-pot—some persons followed him—he walked on slowly until they passed him, then returned and looked at it again, then crossed the road, and appeared to be looking into Wilkinson's house, then returned, took the pot up, put it under his coat, and walked down the lane—I followed him, and on coming near him I suppose he saw me—he put it down on a low wall—I took him into custody, and asked what he had done with the pot—he said, "What pot? I never touched one"—I took the pot off the wall—it was about 100 yards from where
he took it—he was not tipsy—I went to his house, and found another pot there.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you cross the road and take it off the fence your
self? A. No—I did not follow you with it, and put it on the wall—you were walking when I came to you about ten yards from the wall—it is pos
sible I may have played at skittles with you, but I do not recollect being in your company—I never said I would catch you the first opportunity I had because you said you would report me for drinking when on duty—you never said so, and I never said I would have you.
HANNAH WILKINSON . My husband keeps the Old Friends public-house, Garrett-lane, Wandsworth. This pot belongs to him—his name is on it.

Prisoner. Q. What time did you lose it? A. I cannot say, for I send beer out at all hours—I did miss it, but not till the policemen spoke to me—I have lost eight quart and thirteen pint pots, between Christmas-day and the 15th of Feb.—I had mentioned my losses to the policeman.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw the pot hanging on the rails; I passed it about twenty yards, turned round, saw the policeman crossing the road with the pot in his hand; I walked on about 100 yards; he turned and put the pot down on the low wall; I went on, and he took me; I never touched the pot.

WILLIAM LEA
re-examined. The prisoner was 100 yards from the house—there are two or three public-houses and beer-shops in the lane—I did not put the pot on the wall.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Three Months.

835.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for stealing 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 brooch, 12s.; 1 other brooch, 10s.; 1 ring, 17s. 6d.; and 1 Knife 6d.; the goods of
Emma Meggs; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Twelve Months.

836.
ELIZABETH GRADY was indicted
for stealing one purse, value 6d.; 1 half-sovereign, 6 half-crowns, and 1 shilling; the property of
Philip Samuel; and 1 bonnet, 2s., the goods of
Ann Whitley.

PHILIP SAMUEL . I am shopman to Mr. Cohen; the prisoner was servant in the house. On the 14th of Feb. I went to bed about twelve o'clock—I left my trowsers on a chair in the bed-room, with a purse in the pocket, and one half-sovereign, six half-crowns, and one shilling in it—about a quarter after seven next morning I got up, found the pocket turned inside out, and the purse and money gone—the street-door was open and the prisoner gone—she was in the house the night before—I went to the South Western Railway station at Nine Elms—I got there about a quarter after o'clock, and found the prisoner there, going into the train for Gosport—I had her appre
hended she had a bonnet on her head which belonged to the nursery-maid—this purse is mine.

GEORGE WILLIAMS (police-constable V 94) The prisoner was given into my charge by Samuel—I told her she was charged with stealing a purse and 2s. 6d.—she had a bundle in her right hand—she shifted it, and put her right arm under her cloak—I took this purse out of her hand—there was no money in it—she had the bonnet on.
ANN WHITLEY . I live in the house of Solomon Cohen. The prisoner was my fellow-servant—this is the bonnet which I lost.
Prisoner. It is my bonnet, and the one you have on belongs to me. Witness. They are both mine.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

837.
WILLIAM BURFIELD was indicted
for stealing, at St. George the Martyr, in the dwelling-house of
Henry Gander, 1 pocket-book, value 3s.; 1 Bank-note for the payment of 100l.; and 4 Bank-notes for the payment of 50l. each; the property of
Francis George Shaw Skipp.
MESSRS. BALLANTINE and WILD conducted the prosecution.

FRANCIS GEORGE SHAW SKIPP . I am independent, and recently resided at Albert Villa, Finchley. I am now in the Queen's Bench prison—I was arrested for some debts on my return from examination before the Magistrate in this case—on the 26th of Jan. I was stopping at Drummond's Hotel, Euston-square—about that time I received 300l. from Robarts and co.'s the bankers—there was one 100l. note, and four 50l. notes—a person of the name of Last, was stopping with me at the hotel—he is my cousin and brother-in
law as well—we left the hotel about four or five o'clock in the afternoon of the 26th Jan.—I put the money in a pocket-book, and placed the pocket-book in my left boot—Mr. Last saw me put it there—I wore straps, and my trowsers fitted rather tight—it was impossible the pocket-book could get out—we got into a cab, and drove to the North and South American Coffee-house, where we dined—we left there, and after going to various places, arrived at the Catherine-wheel public-house, in the Borough on the morning of the 27th—at about five o'clock a policeman rang the bell for us there—the prisoner came to the door, we asked for beds, and were told there was only one to spare, and we consented both to occupy one bed—we went to the bedroom—the bed stood so that the door of the room was almost opposite the left hand corner of the bed—I placed myself at the foot of the bed—Last went over to the other side of the room—I was sitting at the extreme left hand corner of the bed—at the foot of the bed, opposite the door, and about a yard from the door—the door was about one yard from the left hand corner of the bed—Last was over at the other side of the bed, near the head of the bed on the other side of the room—I was at the foot on the left hand side, and he was at the head at the right hand side—he sat down on the bed at the head, with his back towards me—it was a four-post bedstead, of the ordinary size—the prisoner was there—I sat down on the bed taking my boots off—the prisoner pulled Mr. Last's boots off, I do not know whether I was sitting or standing at that time—I sat down, and put my left hand down on my trowsers, pressing on the boot to push the towards down, in order to undo the straps—in doing so I felt the pocket-book—I pressed on the pocket-book in my boot—finding the strap dirty, I turned to the prisoner and asked him to undo it for me—he undid the strap—Mr. Last was still sitting on the bed at the head, on the right hand side—the prisoner undid my strap, and partly pulled the boot off—in consequence of its being tight, I made the remark, "I think I could get it off better myself"—I kicked it off with the other foot by pressing the toe of the other boot against the heel of my left boot—the prisoner then stopped down—I do not know whether he took the boot or not—he then made the remark, "I must go down to lock my gates"—he went down stairs, lea
ving me with one boot on and one boot off—he returned in three or four minutes—he then undid the other strap, and pulled off the other boot—the whole time the prisoner was absent my brother-in-law was on the other side of the room—he did not move to my knowledge—he did not come to the foot of the bed—he kept at the other side of the room—to the best of my knowledge I think he was sitting the whole time—the prisoner took up my boot or boots, and I said, "Stop, bring those boots back, I have a pocket-book in one of them"—he brought my boots and I turned them

over, and put my hand into them—I found the pocket-book was gone—I said, "Just come inside, I have lost a pocket-book with 300l.—the door was open—he was partly in and partly out—he came in, and I closed the door—he said, "Do you mean to accuse me of robbing you? I have not got it."—I said, "I mean to accuse you of nothing, I have lost my pocket-book, and only wish to find it"—he threw open his jacket, took one or two things from his jacket pocket, a bunch of keys and a handkerchief, making the re
mark, "You may search me"—I lifted his cap from his head, but did not seach him any further—on my going nearer to him he said "Keep your hands off me; do not be after putting anything into my pockets"—we searched at the bottom of the bedstead, where it would have been if it had fallen out of my boot, and also round about the room—I searched myself—he was close to me—we did not entirely search the room till Mr. Gander came—the book not being found I said to the prisoner, "I shall have a policeman"—he said he should call his master. he would not be treated in that way—we went to Mr. Gander, the landlord's room, the prisoner, my brother-in-law, and my
self—the prisoner went partly through the door, which is a kind of small place adjoining the room—it is a small room, closet, or passage, the Prisoner went in and spoke to Mr. Grander—I did not hear what he said—Mr. Gander came out after a little time—he came round to the room where I had my boots pulled off—he said he would not have any disturbance made in his house—he was perfectly satisfied with the honesty of his servant, to which I replied, "I am not satisfied, I have lost 300l., and I must have a police
man; I will have the house searched but what I will have my money found"—Mr. Gander appeared perfectly satisfied, and the only remark he made was, "I do not believe you ever had the money to lose"—he said he was satisfied I had not lost it there, and that his servant had not got it—he said he would have no row in his house—I wished to have the police called, and asked him for the key to get out—he or his servant had the key of the gate that leads into the street—I asked Mr. Gander for the key to get out—he replied it was not his place to open the door—he told the prisoner to leave the room, and go and call another person up—he did not go—that was after I had accused the prisoner of the robbery—I went down to the yard and to the gates, but could not open them—I then went back to the room—the prisoner, my brother-in-law, and I think, Mr. Gander and myself went—the prisoner finally opened the gates and let me out—I think full a quarter of an hour had elapsed since I asked to be let out to get a policeman—I went out and got Hall—he returned with me—by his desire I went out again, leaving him there, and fetched two more policemen, and returned with them and searched the room and gallery—one of the policemen went into Mr. Gander's room—he allowed him to do so—we searched the yard and different carts there and found nothing—the prisoner was in the yard—I said to him, "Now, if you will restore me my pocket-book I will give you ten sovereigns and ask you nothing"—he made some exclamation, puff, or some word of the sort—no person was searched to my knowledge—I heard nothing said about search
ing, with the exception of the prisoner offering to let me search him—in the room, but saying "Keep your hands off." When I went towards him—no person was searched after the policemen came—nothing was said about it, to the best of my memory—we then went to the station, my brother-in-law, the prisoner, the three policemen, and myself—I and my brother-in-law walked together the greater part of the way—it is my impression that we were in front the whole way, but the policeman says not—I do not know the place where the pocket-book is said to have been found—I believe we did pass Adam's-place' as it has been described to me, but I do not know it myself—we were walk
ing

next the road, near the curb—the prisoner was walking next the shops—he was near the shops, the policemen next, Last and myself outside—we did not walk in a row—I cannot say what the width of the pavement is—either Last or myself was on the outside—on the way the prisoner expressed a wish to have coffee two or three times, saying he was thirsty, but he did not—he was searched at the station, and my brother-in-law and myself also, at the request of Mr. Gander—nothing was found.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What age are you? A. I was twenty-tree last July—when I left Drummond's Hotel I went into the City to dine at the North and South American Coffee-house—I went into the City on business with my brother-in-law—I went to two or three places, to Wil
lis's, the Queen's Head public-house, in Newgate-street, to get some sweep
stake tickets—I had dined before I went there—I also wanted to find a Mr. Abbott, who owed me money—I do not know where I went first—I went to one wine and supper-room and one coffee-shop, and to some public-houses—it might be four or five, or five or six places—I do not know how many I drank at—it is most likely that I drank wine and spirits that afternoon, but I do not know how many times—I cannot say whether I went to a dozen public-houses, and drank at a dozen public-houses—I was out twelve hours—I went to the dining-rooms at a quarter to seven—I do not think that I had a dozen glasses of spirits and water that night besides wine—I was perfectly sober—I forget the places I went to after the lapse of time—I was not inebriated—I forget the number of cabs I had that evening—there were a great many things pressing on my mind—I do not know how much I paid for cabs that night—I know the man demanded a great deal more than was right, and I paid him more than his fare—the cab which took us to the Catherine-wheel, we took, I think, in Oxford-street, I will not swear that—I do know where I went to first—I do not think I drank with the cab man—I will not swear I did not—I very often treat the cabmen, if it is late at night—I think we took the last cab about one o'clock—we arrived at the Catherine-wheel about five—I had been to two or three public-houses; to one in the Haymarket, and one just round the corner of the Haymarket—I do not know their names—I do not think that I went to as many as seven public-houses in the last cab, but I cannot tell you—it is very likely I had some supper—I had been going about all night after a person who owed me money—I had slept at the Catherine-wheel before, and knew the house, and knew I should most likely get a bed there—I do not always know where to get a bed at that hour in the morning—I was sleepy, and glad to get to bed—I do not know where we were when I told the cabman to drive there—I went there because I thought it the most likely place to get a bed at—the cabman drove there, and a policeman rang the bell for us; either I, or the cabman, or my brother-in
law, asked him to do so—I do not know the size of the bed-room exactly—it was not a large room—I cannot say the size.

Q. Did you not, when the policeman came, tell him it was no use search
ing the prisoner; that you were satisfied he had not got the pocket-book about him, that you had searched him? A. I never said I had searched him—I said I thought he had not got it about him, because he had been down stairs—I did not put my hands into his pockets; he would not allow me to do so—I did not tell two policemen, James Hall and John Carter, that it was no use searching the prisoner, for he had been searched, and I was satisfied he had not got it about him—I did not put my hand into his jacket or waistcoat pocket—I did not turn out his trowsers' pocket—the prisoner was admitted to bail by the Magistrate, and has been at liberty ever since.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Just look at those two policemen, (Carter and

Hall) are those two of them which came there? A. I believe they are; I think Asiter is the other—it was Hall that sent me away to get the other policemen—I left him behind—the prisoner came down to let me out at the gate—I was gone four or five minutes—the prisoner did not offer any resistance to the police—I saw nothing that rendered it necessary, on account of resistance, for there to be two more policemen—I am quite certain I did not tell the policemen I had searched the prisoner—my object in going about that night was to find Abbott, and draw some tickets at Willis's and at Mackintosh's, near Westminster-bridge, and there might have been two or three more places—I know the landlord of the Catherine-wheel by sight—he is now in Court.

GEORGE LAST . I am cousin and brother-in law to the prosecutor; he married my sister. I was with him on this occasion, the 26th of Jan.—I remained with him till we arrived at the Catherine-wheel—we were taken up into a bed-room there; and my boots were taken off by the prisoner, I then began to undress—I was on the left-hand side of the bed as you enter the room—I was nearer the head of the bed than the foot, about the middle, at the side of it—my cousin was on the foot of the bed—I saw one of his boots taken off—it was partly taken off, and then he kicked it off—the prisoner then went out of the room—I did not move from the side of the bed where I was until my cousin got up—that was after the prisoner had returned—he had just come into the doorway—I then got up—I did not see the other boot taken off—my cousin went to the door, and hallooed out for him to bring the boot back—he came back, and my cousin asked him if he had seen the pocket-book—I do not know whether he had his other boot off or not—I had not been drinking, and was not drunk—I had been drinking in the evening, but not for two or three hours previously—I was saber—I neither touched or saw this pocket-book in any way whatever.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been with your brother-in-law from the time you left Drummond's hotel? A. Yes—I had been staying with him three or four months—that was in the country—I have been with him in London about six weeks—we were at two or three different places in London—we had been at the Camden hotel, Russell-street, Convent-garden, at the Garrick's Head, in Bow-street, and at Drummond's, near Euston-square—until that night, I had not been in the habit of going about with him to public-houses—I think we took the cab in the New-road that took us to the Catherine-wheel—we had been in two or three cabs during the day—I swear we had not been in five or six—we went into five or six public-houses, coffee-shops, betting-rooms, Derby sweepstake places, and wine-rooms—my brother-in-law has been married about two or three years—my sister is in the country—my brother-in-law was trying to avoid his creditors—I cannot say what time we had the last cab that day—we changed cabs at about seven or eight o'clock—we dined in the city—we got into the last cab, that took us to the Catherine-wheel, about eight or nine, or nine or ten o'clock, or somewhere thereabouts—I think we got out of one cab into another—I do not know what we paid the one we got out of—we had ridden in it two or three hours—I drank brandy and water, gin and water, ale, stout, and half
and
half—no neat spirits nor wine—I am nineteen years old—I had not been on the spree in London for a month—we amused ourselves during the day time—I sometimes went by the name of Best—I never went by the name of west—I gave the name of Best on account of my brother's creditors—I never gave it before—my brother went by his proper name, except at the police-court—I have been a linen-draper's shopman, at Brighton, and in other

situations, all in the drapery line—at the Catherine-wheel I saw my brother just lift the prisoner's cap off his head—he did not put his hands into the prisoner's jacket or waistcoat pocket, or turn out his pocket—the prisoner turned out two or three of his pockets—I cannot say as to whether it was his trowsers or waistcoat pocket—he threw open his jacket, and unbuttoned his waistcoat—I am quite sure I did not see his trowsers pocket hanging out—when in the last cab I had noticed a bulge in my brother-in-law's trowsers as he sat on the seat opposite me—he was married to my sister three or four years ago—she is twenty-three or twenty-four years of age.

JAMES HALL (police-constable M 101.) On Wednesday morning I was on duty in High-street, Borough, about a quarter past five—my attention was drawn to a cab, which stopped at the Catherine-wheel—I rang the bell, and the prisoner came to the door—I saw two persons alight from the cab, whom I have subsequently found out were Mr. Skipp and Mr. Last—I saw those two get out of the cab—about half an hour after I again saw Mr. Skipp—in consequence of what he said, I went back with him to the Cathe
rine
wheel—Mr. Gander, the proprietor, Mr. West, Mr. Skipp, and the prisoner were there—they were standing in the yard—Mr. Skipp asked for a light to go up and search the bedroom—Mr. Gander said he was not going to have people there searching his premises, making a noise to disturb his lodgers—I then told Mr. Skipp he had better go and get another officer—he went, and returned with two others—I then asked for a light to go and search the bedroom—Mr. Gander then said he was not going to allow people there to search his premises, making a noise, and disturbing his lodgers—I heard Mr. Skipp tell the other two officers he had searched the prisoner himself, and was satisfied he had not got it about his person—a light was brought—Carter, myself, and Mr. Skipp went up stairs and searched the bedroom, and found nothing—the prisoner was given into custody when we came down—Asiter I believe would have searched him—the prisoner then opened his waist
coat, and said, "You may come and search me again if you like"—Mr. Skipp then said it was useless to search him for he had searched him, and was satisfied he had not got the money about his person—that is the reason he was not searched—he was taken to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. Just describe the order in which you walked to the station? A. The prisoner, with me, proceeded first—he was on my right hand side, inside—Carter, Mr. West, and Mr. Skipp followed at a little dis
tance behind—we went in that order about halfway to the station—then they passed us—the prisoner and me were in front when we passed Adam's place, which is about twenty yards from the Catherine-wheel.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you hold of the prisoner? A. I had hold of his arm at one time, but he seemed very willing to go—I had neither trouble nor difficulty—it did not require any assistance to take him to the station—I have never been in the Catherine-wheel before, and did not know the landlord—my brother constable had charge of Skipp and Last—it is generally necessary for a policeman to go with the prosecutor to the station—the prisoner was inside me the whole of the way—I was holding one arm part of the way—he was searched by the sergeant at the station—a complaint has been lodged against me about not having searched him before.

COURT. Q. was any complaint lodged against you for not having searched him at the Catherine-wheel? A. There has been a complaint—we have to wait till this trial is over—the reason I did not search him is because Mr. Skipp said it was quite unnecessary—that is the reason I shall give to the Commissiones.

HENRY ASITER (police-constable M 30.) On the morning of 27th Jan. I was called to the Catherine-wheel inn—I stood by the prisoner while the other constable went and searched the room—Carter went with me, as he was on the adjoining beat, I called him across the road—the prisoner was given into custody, and taken to the station-house—I did not go with them—I was left in the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear Mr. Skipp say he had searched the prisoner? A. He told me so at St. George's church, about 200 yards from the Catherine-wheel—he did not say he had searched the prisoner—he said he had been searched—that was on the way to the Catherine-wheel, before we went there—he had fetched me.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did he tell you had searched him? A. He said he had been searched, and he was confident he had not got it about him—that was the reason I did not search him—I am included in the report—we have had to give a written statement of the circumstances to our inspector, Mr. Yates—we were given to understand the Commissioners had seen the account in the newspapers, and that we were complained of, for not searching the prisoner at the Catherine-wheel—I first heard that, the day after the se
cond examination.
JOHN CARTER (police-constable M 191.) examined by Mr. CLARKSON. I heard Mr. Skipp say it was of no use searching the prisoner, as he had been searched, and he was satisfied he had not got it.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you been reported to the Commissioners for not searching him? A. I believe we have—we have not been before the Commissioners—I have not heard anything about it standing over—we have given a statement to the inspector.

JOHN SHELLY YATES (inspector of the M Division.) The prisoner was brought to the station by two constable, on the 27th—I produce a pocket-book which I received from a person of the name of Munro—when I received it, there were four 50l. and one 100l. notes in it—I took the numbers of them—they have been given up to Mr. Skipp's attorney—I am quite sure that it is the pocket-book, and that those notes were in it when they came to the station—the prosecutor was sober—he perfectly understood what he was about—Mr. Last was sober.

WILLIAM MUNRO . I am in the service of the Phoenix Gas company. I remember on the morning of the 27th Jan. receiving a pocket-book from a person of the name of Cox—I gave it to Yates—I saw it when it had the four 50l. and the one 100l. note in it.

WILLIAM COX . I am a servant to the Phoenix Gas Company, at Bankside. On the morning of the 27th Jan. I left my house at about ten minutes to six, to go to work—I had to pass by Adam's-place—I passed there about four or five minutes to six—in doing so, I kicked against something which turned out to be a pocket-book—it was nearly in the middle of the pavement—I did not observe it till I kicked against it—it was very near Adam's-place, not quite opposite—I know the Catherine-wheel, and the station-house also—Adam's-place is in the road from the Catherine-wheel to the station-house—it is about twenty-two yards or paces from the centre of the gate of the Catherine-wheel—I handed the pocket-book to Mr. Munro, in the state I found it.

FRANCIS GEORGE SHAW SKIPP
re-examined. The left boot, in which the pocket-book was, was the first that was taken off.

GUILTY . Aged 59.—
Confined Six Months.

838.
JOHN SHARPE was indicted
for unlawfully publishing obscene pictures and prints; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One year,
and to enter into recognizances.

839.
JOHN WILSON and
HENRY SMALLBONES were indicted for
stealing 2 chairs, value 15s., the goods of
Robert Lake; and that Wilson had been before convicted of felony; to which

WILSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

WILLIAM MORTON (police-sergeant, P 7.) I was in company with another policeman, about five o'clock in the evening of the 14th of Jan., in Old Kent-road—I saw the two prisoners together—I followed them till about half-past six o'clock—they passed and re-passed several shops—I saw them come to Mr. Lake's, a furniture-dealers, by the Bricklayers' Arms—they passed and re-passed—they were still together—I then saw an arm reach down two chairs, which were resting on a couch parlty inside—Smith, the officer, ran across the road, and the prisoner, Wilson, ran towards me—I caught him in my arms, and he fell under the belly of a horse—he had nothing with him—he began to kick me over the legs and thighs—I saw that he ran from Mr. Lake's shop—I charged him with stealing two chairs—he made no reply—I then asked if he understood what I said—he said he did not understand it at all.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Where were you? A. Near the Swan—I was perhaps fifty yards distance from the prisoner, across the road—it was dark—I saw the prisoners together about a minute before the chairs were taken.

HENRY DUFF (police-constable P 136.) I was with Morton. I saw the prisoners together for one hour and twenty minutes—I saw them pass and re-pass Mr. Lake's shop for about a quarter of an hour—I saw Wilson with one or two chairs in his arms—Smith ran to him, and Wilson ran from him into the arms of Morton—I ran and saw Smallbones about 200 yards off, looking back to see if anybody was following him—I said to him, "Come back to your mate"—he said, "You have not seen me do anything—it was not me that took the chairs"—I had not said anything to him about chairs.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first say you saw Smallbones looking back? A. I said so in my evidence before the Magistrate—this is my signa-ture to this deposition—I said, "I ran in the direction I thought Smallbones was gone, and overtook him—he was walking when I overtook him."

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable P 302.) I was in the Kent-road—Morton called my attention to the two prisoners—I saw them together for ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—I saw Wilson take the two chairs off a couch or sofa—he walked away with them towards New Cross—I went towards him—he threw the chairs on my feet, and in stepping to catch him, I stepped on one of the chairs, and broke it—Wilson ran into Morton's arms—I saw Smallbones with Wilson together a minute before he took the chairs.

JOHN DANIEL BLAIN . I am shop-boy to Mr. Robert Lake—he is a furniture-dealer, and lives in the Old Kent-road. On the 14th of Jan. I saw Wilson take the chairs off the sofa, and walk away—I ran after him, and stopped him—I did not see Smallbones at that time—I had seen them together about five minutes before—these are my master's chairs.

SMALLBONES—
NOT GUILTY .

840.
JOHN NOLAN was indicted
for assaulting
Eleanor France, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of a common Assault. Aged 38.—
Confined One Month.

841.
THOMAS CONNOLLY was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

842.
CHARLOTTE SPRINGFIELD was indicted
for a like offence.

MESSRS. CLARKE and LAW conducted the Prosecution. ELIZABETH PERCY. I am the daughter of James Percy, a dairyman, in Friar-street, Lambeth. On Thursday night, the 14th of Jan., about nine o'clock, the prisoner came for a pint of milk, and gave me a bad half-crown—I gave it to my brother, who bent it and returned it to me—he told the prisoner it was a bad one, and he would keep it—she said, "If the young man intends to keep it, I will go and fetch my husband"—she went out—my brother followed her—I laid the half-crown on the mantel-piece—we kept it in the shop till the officer came, and I showed it him—sergeant Goff took it off the counter—I am quite sure he took the same half-crown the prisoner gave me—I saw him take it from the counter—that was a week afterwards—it had remained on the shelf about a week—no one was there but me—I then desired my brother to nail it and another piece of bad money on the counter—I know it to be the one the prisoner gave me by the teeth-marks next to the crown—the same marks were on it when it was put on the shelf—my brother had marked it with his teeth.

RICHARD PERCY . I am the brother of Elizabeth Percy. I recollect her receiving this half-crown—I placed it between my teeth, and bent it—the prisoner was in the shop, standing at the door—I said, "I shall keep this"—she said, "If the young man is going to keep it, I shall fetch my husband"—she left the shop—I gave the half-crown to my sister, and followed the prisoner some distance—I then lost sight of her—I saw the half-crown again when I went back, on the mantel-shelf behind the counter—it remained there nearly a week—I saw it on the shelf during the week—my brother then nailed it on the counter—I can say it was the same, by my teeth marks and by the way I bent it.
Prisoner. When I was taken up you could not say whether it was me or not. Witness. I swear to her by her face.
JAMES PERCY . I am the brother of Richard Percy. I saw a bad half-crown in my father's shop—I nailed it on the counter about a fortnight after the prisoner brought it in.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) On Friday, the 29th of Jan., I went to Mr. Percy's house, and saw a half-crown nailed to the counter—I took it away—Elizabeth Percy was present—I produce the half-crown.

ALICE HOSKINS . I am the wife of John Hoskins; we live in Vauxhall-road. On the 17th of Jan. the prisoner came for a pint of milk, which came to 2d.—she gave me a half-crown—I felt it was smooth on the head side—I looked at her—(I knew she had passed a bad 5s. piece to me last summer)—I told her I had I had not got change—I went down to Mr. Hawkins's shop, and showed the half-crown to her—I came back to my house and I said to the prisoner, "I shall not give you this money, nor the mug; you well knew this was a bad one"—she said she did not; she would go and fetch her husband—she went out—I followed but lost her in Francis-street—I put the half-crown on

a table, under a mug—the policeman came the next day, and told me to take care of it—I marked it, put it into a bit of paper, and marked it with the day of the month and the year—I put it into a drawer, where it remained till the 1st of Feb., when I gave it to the officer Stickley.
Prisoner. Q. If you were aware it was bad, why did you want to go to a shop to get change? A. To have a witness that it was bad.

RICHARD STICKLEY (police-constable L 79.) On the 18th of Jan. I went to Mr. Hoskins's house—she produced a half-crown, and marked it in my presence—I did not take it away then—on the 1st of Feb. she gave me the same half-crown—it was in the same paper, and marked with the day of the month.

LOUISA URSELL . I am the wife of John Ursell; I assist in the shop of Mr. Elliot. On the 28th of Jan., about nine o'clolck in the evening, the pri
soner came for an ounce of 4s. tea, and half a pound of sugar—they came to 7d.—she put a crown-piece on the counter—I took it up, and found it was bad—I handed it to Mr. Elliott, who was standing by my side—he asked the prisoner where she lived—she said, "At No. 9, in this street," pointing to some street—he asked where she got it—she said her husband had given it her, and she would fetch him, and went out—I said I would not let it pass off, and Mr. Elliott went with her.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not drop it into the till, and then pick it up and say, "I don't think this is a good one?" A. No, I put it into no till at all.

CHARLES ELLIOTT . I keep a shop at No. 14, Barrett-street, Lambeth. On the evening of the 28th of Jan. I saw the prisoner between eight and nine o'clock—she was served by Louisa Ursell, who handed a crown-piece to me, and said she did not think it was good—I had seen the prisoner give it her—I looked at it, and asked the prisoner where she got it—she said her hus
band gave it her—I asked where she lived—she said, "At No. 9, down Little Park-street"—I went with her—she led me down a street or two, and then I met an officer, who took her.
Prisoner. She dropped it in the till? Witness. No, on my oath she did not—the till was not open.
JAMES PIPER (police-constable L 76) On the 28th of Jan. I met the prisoner and Mr. Elliott in New-street—I took the prisoner—I asked her where she lived—she said, anywhere, where she could get money.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint—these half-crowns are both counterfeit, and I believe have been cast in the same mould—this crown-piece is also counterfeit in all respects.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know it was bad; I am an unfortunate girl; I said my husband gave it me, not being aware what it was; the two half-crowns I know nothing at all about.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months

843.
ELIZABETH HALEY and
JOHN PEEL were indicted for
a like offence.

ANN ROOK . I am the wife of George Rook, who keeps a chandler's shop in Creek-place, Bermondsey. On the evening of the 19th Feb., between eight and nine o'clock, Haley came for a half-quartern loaf, and gave me a shilling in payment—I noticed it was a lion shilling—I put it into the till, where there were two other shillings—Haley went away—when she was gone West, the policeman came in—I looked in the till, I found the shilling with
the lion on, and it was bad—the other two shillings were good, and they had not lions—I bit the lion shilling and gave it to the officer.
Haley. I was not in the shop. Witness. She is the woman.

SARAH TORY . I am a window—I keep a chandler's shop in Albert-place Bermondsey. On Friday evening, the 19th of Feb., Haley came for half an ounce of tea, which came to 1 3/4 d.—she gave me a sixpence—I gave her 4 1/4 d. change—I put the sixpence in the till—the policeman came in instantly, and asked me what she had given me—I took it out and gave it him—he told me to mark it, an I did—there was no other sixpence in the till.

CATHERINE HASLER . I am the wife of George Hasler—he keeps the Ship public-house at Horslydown. On Friday evening, the 19th of Feb., at a quarter before nine o'clock, Haley came in for a pint of porter, and brought her own jug—I served her, and she gave me a shilling—the policeman was there—he came and told me the woman was offering me bad money—I had not laid the shilling out of my hand—I gave it to him and he took her—I asked where she got it and she told me at the Kent-road.

JOHN WHITLAMB (police-constable M 89) On the 19th of Feb. I was in company with West, in plain clothes—I saw the prisoners in company toge
ther in Long-lane, Bermondsey, proceeding in a direction to Mr. Rook's shop—I saw them pass the shop, and at a few yards distance they stood talking for about a minute—Haley went into the shop, and Peel looked in the shop while Haley was in—when Haley came out she went down a turning and stood in the dark till Peel joined her—they then proceeded till they came to Mr. Tory's shop—Haley went in, leaving Peel outside—I saw him pass and repass the shop, and he stood in a dark turning—Haley came out of the shop, they joined again, and went to the Ship—Haley left Peel and went to the bar—she called for a pint of beer, and I saw her lay this shilling down—I cautioned Mr. Hasler, and said she was taking bad money—Haley said she was in the habit of coming in there every night, and if it was bad she did not know it; that she had taken it for some work she had done in the Kent-road—while I was talking to her Peel came in, and was secured.

THOMAS WEST (police-constable M 249.) On the 19th of Feb. I was in company with Whitlamb—I saw the two prisoners in company in Long-lane—they went on to Mr. Rook's shop—Haley went in, and when she came out I went in and received a shilling—I came out and found the prisoners again in company—they went to Mr. Tory's—Haley left Peel a little dis
tance from the shop—she went into the shop, and as soon as she came out I went in and received this sixpence—I came out and saw Peel with the loaf of bread which Haley had brought out of Rook's shop—they then went to the Ship at Shad Thames—Haley went in, leaving Peel outside—he then went in—I followed and took him—I found on him two sixpences, 7 1/2 d. in coppers, some sugar, and a little tea—I told him I wanted him for uttering base coin with the woman—he said he never saw her before—on the way to the station Haley said, "What is this young man taken for?"—I said for being con
nected with her, in passing counterfeit coin—she said she never saw him before.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These two shillings are both counterfeit, and from the same mould—the sixpence is also counterfeit.

Haley's Defence. This man is a perfect stranger to me; what they say against us is quite false; he never was in company with me at all; I was not aware the shilling I had was a bad one; the lady had not time to tell me whether it was bad or good.

HALEY—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

PEEL—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

844.
BENJAMIN PURSEY was indicted
for stealing 2 20l. Bank-notes, the monies of
James Glassford Gooding, in his dwelling-house; to which he pleaded

GUILTY, Aged 33.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

845.
JOSEPH LIDDAMAN was indicted
for embezzling 1l., and 1l. 3s. 6d., which he received on account of his master,
John Dawson; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY , Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

846.
JOHN MIDDLETON was indicted
for stealing 1 gallon of oats, beans, and chaff, mixed, value 1s. 6d.; and 5lbs. weight of straw, value 2d.; the goods of
George Alexander Wall, others; to which he pleaded

GUILTY , Aged 40.—
Confined One Month.

847.
JAMES MAXWELL was indicted
for stealing 1 bricklayer's trowel, values 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Turner; to which he pleaded

GUILTY , Aged 39.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

848.
RICHARD FARRELL was indicted for
stealing 30lbs. weight of twine, value 1l., the goods of
William Bennett; and
SAMUEL MORRIS
for feloniously receiving part of the same, well knowing, it to be stolen.

WILLIAM BENNETT . I live in Worcester-street, Union-street, Southwark, I am a twine-manufacturer. On the 12th of Feb. I sent twelve bundles of twine by my servant, to Abney-street, Horsleydown—I saw one of them in possession of the officer the same evening—this is one of the twelve bundles, and is mine.

JOHN HOLLAND . I am in Mr. Bennett's employ. I was sent by him on the 12th of Feb., to Abney-street, with twelve bundles of twine, in a truck—this is one of the bundles—I went to Mr. Edgington's factory, and left my truck, in order to get one of the men to open the gates—there were twelve bundles in the truck when I got to the gates, and when I came out of Mr. Edgington's factory I missed two—I had been absent about a minute, and then two bundles were gone—I had seen Farrell in Collingwood-street—I asked him to give me a lift with my truck through the snow, and he helped me to push it as far as Edgington's—he then asked me for 1d. for half-a
pint of beer, and I said I had not a farthing.

PHILIP DAVIES . I saw Holland drawing the truck, assisted by Farrell—I saw the truck stop at Edgington's gate—Farrell went from the truck to Three Oak-lane, opposite my house—Holland went into Edgington's—I saw Farrell return to the truck and take two bundles of twine out, and run off with them—I sent my servant to give information to Edgington.

JOSEPH ROYLE KNOWLES . I am a marine-store dealer, and live in Tooley-street. Between six and seven o'clock in the evening, on the 12th of Feb., Morris brought me a bundle of twine to sell—I asked him what he wanted for it—he said a groat a pound—I should have to give about 10d. a pound for it—I gave my boy 1s., with a pretence of getting change, and sent for a policeman, and gave Morris in charge—I had heard there was twine stolen.

Morris. A man came and asked me to sell it—he said he would give me a pint of beer—he said, "Ask 4d. a pound for it"—I said I was led into an error. Witness, No, he brought it in a small bag—he left the twine on the counter, and he went out and gave the bag to a boy, who, I believe, was the other prisoner.

WILLIAM ROWE (police-sergeant M 10.) A lad came for me—I went to Mr. Knowles's shop, and received charge of Morris and this bundle of twine—I asked Morris where he got it—he said he met a man in Tooley-street, who asked him to sell it, and he would give him a pint of beer, and he was to ask 4d. a pound for it—he said he did not know the man.

JOHN COOMSS (police-constable M 252.) I took Farrell into custody in Hunter-street, New Kent-road—he was given into my custody by Mr. Jen
nings.
Morris's Defence. I was out seeking for work, and I was asked to take the twine to sell for a trifling remuneration.

FARRELL—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

MORRIS—
GUILTY. Aged 51.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against Farrell.)

849.
JAMES MACKEY,
JAMES WRIGHT , and
DAVID LYNCH , were indicted for
stealing 84lbs. weight of coals, value 10d., the goods of
Andrew Spottiswoode; and that Wright had been before convicted of felony, to which

LYNCH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Whipped, and discharged.

AUSTIN EDWARD GANS (Thames police-constable No. 68.) I was on shore at Vauxhall, near the gas-works, on the 22nd of Feb., about half-past one o'clock in the afternoon—I saw the three prisoners go down a draw-dock close to the gas-works—they went directly to a coal-barge called the Glasgow, belonging to Mr. King—the property in it belonged to Mr. Spottiswood—I saw Mackey looking about him—he then jumped on the gunwale of the barge, took a large piece of coal, and put it by the side of the barge—he got up a second time, and took another large piece—he got up a third time, and then Lynch lifted Wright up, and they both took a piece, chucked them out of the barge, and deposited them alongside of the barge—Mackey and Wright got up a second time, both together, and took another piece—they then each took a piece under their arms—I ran round the barge, and took Mackey—the other two were taken by another officer.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you hear Mackey say he had met these boys, and been induced to go with them? A. Yes.
JOHN WILLIAM TAYLOR . I was with Gans, and assisted in taking the prisoners.
GEORGE YOUNG . I am clerk to Mr. Andrew Spottiswoode, a coal-merchant, at Vauxhall—the coals in the Glasgow barge belonged to him.

THOMAS LOCKYER (police-constant L 137.) I produce a certificate of Wright's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 15th June, 1846, and confined three months)—I had know him four times summarily convicted previous to that.
(The prisoner Mackey received a good character.)

MACKEY—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Whipped, and discharged.

WRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Confined One Month, and
Whipped ,

850.
WILLIAM CHURCHILL and
THOMAS HIGGINS were in
dicted for
stealing 43lbs. weight of lead, value 5s., the goods of the
South
wark and Vauxhall Water Company.
THOMAS BENT (police-constable V 95.) On Thursday evening. 4th Feb.,

I saw the prisoners in Nine Elms-lane, walking together—Churchill had a bundle over his right arm—I followed, and asked Churchill what he had got there—he said he had a piece of lead—I asked where he got it—he said he had brought it from the Water-works, where he was at work, and was going to take it to Mr. Hemmings, his master—I asked him if I went to Mr. Hem
mings, whether he would know he was going to bring it—he said no, but the foreman had told him to take it—I asked Higgins if he had heard the foreman say so—he said yes, it was all right—I went to Mr. Morland, the foreman, but the prisoners were not present—I had left them with another constable—in consequence of what I heard at Mr. Morland's I went and took the prisoners to the station-house—they were about three-quarters of a mile from the Water-works, coming towards Westminster—I produce the lead—here are 43lbs. of it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What Churchill said was perfectly true, that it was lead, and that Mr. Hemmings was his master? A. Yes, and he had been working at the Water-works—Regent-street leads out of Horseferry-road—they were going in a direction towards that—both the Prisoners were admitted to bail.

JAMES MORLAND . I am foreman to Mr. Hemmings, of Regent-street—he is a stone-mason—the prisoners were employed by me on the premises of the Southwark and Vauxhall Water-works—I did not direct either of them to take away any lead from the premises—I was working there—I cannot say that I saw any of this lead on the premises—there was lead about, but in much larger sheets than this—this is my signature to this deposition—I think it was read over to me.

Q. Here you say, "There was a good deal of such lead as this produced, lying about on the premises." A. I said there was a great quantity of lead, but I was not aware that there was any of this sort about—there was sheet lead about there.

JOHN HANCOCK . I am engineer to the Southwark and Vauxhall Water
works Company—I live on the works—there was lead similar to this on the Premises—it was the property of the Water-Works Company.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you venture to swear that this lead ever belonged to the Company? A. No—there has been lead used similar to this—I could not go so far as to swear that this was the lead—these men were working at flooring, in stone-work—I suppose they might have to remove rubbish at times—they had a large job—it had been going on seven or eight months—there were a lot of things taken away, fresh things brought, and rubbish and other things moved.
COURT. Q. Would any person have a right to remove these sort of things by way of rubbish? A. Not to my knowledge.
MR. PAYNE to JAMES MORLAND. Q. Would it be the duty if these men to carry away rubbish? A. Yes—they have to clear away the rubbish after the work is complete.
NOT GUILTY .

851.
JOHN BARNARD was indicted
for stealing 14 quarts of beans, value 3s., the goods of
James Harvey, his master.

WILLIAM REED (police-constable V 18.) Between six and seven o'clock on the evening of the 5th Feb. I was at St. Ann's-hill, Wandsworth, and saw the prisoner—he had a bag, containing some beans, under his arm—I stopped him, and asked him what he had got there—he said, "Some corn"—I asked where he was going to take it—he said, "To a friend"—I asked if his master was aware he was going to take it—he said, "No"—I took him back to Mr. Harvey, who asked how he came to take these beans—he said, "Out of bravado,

to see if I could carry them so far without being stopped by the police"—Mr. Harvey said it was very wrong in him to take them away—he said he had taken them from the bin out of the other beans—there were fourteen quarts of them—I produce a sample of them, and a sample of beans from the stable.

JAMES HARVEY . The prisoner had been in my employ for twelve months—I had no complaint of him—he had no authority to take these beans—a better servant no man could have—I would have no hesitation in taking him again.
NOT GUILTY .

852.
ELIZA HARRISON,
MARGARET HOARE , and
CAROLINE ALBURY were indicted for
stealing 35 yards of ribbon, value 11s., the goods of
Catherine Clark.

WILLIAM CLEAR . I live with my uncle, in Blackman-street, Borough. On the afternoon of Tuesday, 2nd Feb., I saw the three prisoners at our shop—I afterwards watched, and saw them go into Mr. Clark's shop—I then saw two of them come out, and the other one shortly afterwards—it was then about four o'clock—I watched them for more than an hour.

WILLIAM CLARK . I am the son of Catherine Clark, a widow, who carries on the business of a draper, in Waterloo-road. On the afternoon of 2nd Feb. the three prisoners came into our shop—Albury asked for some lace—I showed her some—she said there was none to suit her—there was a collar on the counter—one of the prisoners took it in her hand—my mother saw them from the parlour window—she came and took it from her—they then left the shop—Clear came in, and from what he said, I looked into the window, and missed some ribbon, which I had placed there about half an hour before—it was not on a block, but loose—clear and I then followed the prisoners—they went to the New-road, and stopped at Mr. Lawrence's shop—we saw them take something from there—they then went into a kind of recess—I went for a policeman—we found them together, and charged them with having taken the ribbon—they said they had not taken it, and did not know anything about it—I saw the ribbon in Hoare's hand—she said it was not mine—I gave them in charge—when we got to the station, I did not see the ribbon again—I knew the ribbon—it was my mother's—there were thirty-five yards of it, as near as I can guess.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. You had some suspicion about these women? A. My mother had—we took them about ten minutes after they left out shop—I do not know what was done with the ribbon—the prisoners were searched—some wafers were found on them—we had only that one piece of ribbon in our window—I saw the ribbon after I brought the policeman—I said in his presence, "That is my ribbon"—the prisoners were taken to the station, and no ribbon found—Hoare had it in her hand in the street.
WILLIAM WELLS (police-constable L 84.) I heard Clark speak about the ribbon—I did not see any—I took the prisoners to the station. but no ribbon was found.
Hoare. They were the strings of my bonnet which I had in my hand.
NOT GUILTY .

853.
ELIZA HARRISON,
MARGARET HOARE , and
CAROLINE ALBURY were again indicted for
stealing 1 cap, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Cleare.

WILLIAM CLEARE . I live with my uncle, Charles Cleare, in Blackman-street. On Tuesday afternoon, the 2nd of Feb., I was in the shop—the prisoners came in—Harrison asked for a border—she was shown some—she

was standing at the counter—the other two prisoners were at a recess—Harrison said the collars were not what she wanted—I went to the end of the counter, and watched the other two prisoners at the recess—I saw Hoare drop a cap from her cloak—I saw it fall—I saw it at her side by her cloak—there was no cap on the ground before that—it was my uncle's—I had seen it before the prisoners came into the shop—my uncle charged them with stealing it—Hoare denied it, and said she picked it up from the floor—it could not have fallen—it could not have been brushed off by the cloak—it was too high for that—after Mr. Cleare had scolded the prisoners, they went away—he told me to watch them—they walked together, and went into a pawn
broker's-shop—they came out, and went into another pawnbroker's—two of them went in, and one stood outside—they went into a public-house n the Waterloo-road together, and then they went to Mr. Clark's together—Mr. Clark then followed, and gave them in custody—I saw the ribbon in the hand of Hoare at the time.
WILLIAM WELLS . I know no more than taking the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

854.
ELIZA HARRISON,
MARGARET HOARE , and
CAROLINE ALBURY were again indicted for
stealing 400 wafers, value 8d., the goods of
Edward Lawrence.
No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

855.
WILLIAM KING , was indicted
for stealing 12 pieces of wood, value 1s., the goods of
Benjamin Bobbins, his master.

WILLIAM LEE (police-constable V 38.) I was on duty at East-hill, Wandsworth, at a quarter-past five o'clock in the afternoon of the 4th of Feb., and met the prisoner carrying some wood in a basket—I stopped him and asked him where he brought it from—he said from where he lived, at an unoccupied house, opposite the Swan—I stopped him about 100 yards from Mr. Bobbin's—this is the wood.

CHRISTOPHER CASTLE (police-constable V 123.) I saw the prisoner stopped—I examined the wood—it had marks on it, which I had put on it the night before, when it was in a basket, in a stable at Mr. Bobbin's.
Prisoner. Q. You did not mark it before you saw it in the basket? A. No.

BENJAMIN FOULGER . I am gardener to Mr. Benjamin Bobbin, of East
hill—he employed the prisoner as a gardener for some days—he was employed on Thursday, the 4th of Feb.—this wood is Mr. Bobbin's—they are pieces for fire-wood, and were cut on Mr. Bobbin's premises for the use of his house—the prisoner had no permission to take any—he had been employed to lop tress—it is not his perquisite to have any of the lopping.

Prisoner. It is a usual custom to have a basket of wood when lopping or topping trees; I put the wood into a basket two days before I took it home, and hung it over a cinder-box, where the servants always go; the stable
door stood open for two days, and the night before I went, I put it in the stable and locked it up; somebody opened it again; I told them where I brought it from.
NOT GUILTY .

856.
JOHN FRANKLIN was indicted
for stealing 9lbs. of lead, value 1s. 3d.; 1 dusting-brush, value 1s.; and one other brush, value 1s.; the goods of
William Charnock, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY Aged 34—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Weeks.

857.
JOHN CLARK was indicted
for stealing 1 half-crown, 14 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Catherine Malone, from her person.

CATHERINE MALONE . I am single, and live at No. 1, Three Kings-court, Whitecross-court—I have lived there since I left my situation, six or seven weeks ago. I have been acquainted with the prisoner better than twelve months—he proposed to marry me about a month ago—for about two or three months he had never stopped from my place—in consequence of his request, I left my situation, and went to live with my sister—after that he wanted money to furnish him with some clothes, and I let him have it—he imposed on me the belief that he was going to marry me, and I furnished him with money to rig himself out—he then took me to buy a wedding-ring at my own expense, and then persuaded me to give him money to buy furniture, a table and chairs, and to take a room—he represented that he had collected articles in the room—he asked me for the key of the room to put an article in—I went very early the next morning for it, and could not get it—I found the banns were not put up where he said they were—Tuesday, the 16th of Feb., was fixed on for our marriage—he appointed Mr. Swaine's lodging, near Cripplegate church, to meet me to go to get married—I found him there—in going, as I supposed, to church, when we got to Aldersgate-street we went to a public-house—we had some refreshment, and I changed a sovereign—I had 17s. or 18s. in my pocket—I sat down near the prisoner—he asked me to show him what money I had in my pocket—I was not in the act of counting it—I had changed a sovereign, and I had my hand in my pocket, putting the money in—he reached over and snatched my money from my hand—he turned the pocket up, and took every farthing of money—I resisted—I put my hand on his, and said, "You have got every farthing of money I have, and I could take better care of it than you"—he said, "It would look very stupid of me, when we get to church, not to have the money to pay the fees, but to have to ask you for it"—he assigned that as a reason for taking it from me—we got into a cab, and when got out, he pointed to a church just by, and said, "That is the church"—he took me to another public-house, and then he cut away through the courts, leaving me to pay the cab,—I had not a farthing, but my sister, who was with me, had a few shillings, or else we should all have been given in charge—I afterwards found the prisoner in Red Lion-court, wearing the coat I had bought for him—I asked him for the ring and the money be thieved out of my pocket—he said he had lost the ring.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How many friends were with you? A. Two, my sister Margaret, and a young English lady, Elizabeth Sperring—they were in the public-house—Mr. Swaine was there—the prisoner was on my left-hand side—I had no one on the other side—the prisoner was not at a distance—my pocket was on my right side, and he put his hand down, and turned out what was in my pocket—Mr. Swaine and Elizabeth Sperring were at other end, and the table between us—there was no one near me and the prisoner—my sister saw what was going on—she was not with the others—Mr. Swaine's back was turned to me—the other young woman and herself saw nothing, but they heard the making mention of a few words—I thought that money would be expended in the marriage fees—the prisoner said he was to give it to the clergyman.

Q. Did he not say he intended to carry the money because he intended to wear the breeches? A. I wanted to have the money back, and he said, "What I have I will keep, because I will wear the breeches"—that was after he had got the money—he did not count the money, for he put it into his pocket as soon as he took it.

COURT. Q. Tell us exactly what occurred at the time your money was taken? A. After coming in from the bar I had the money in my hand—I counted it after getting change at the bar—it was all right—I had 17s. or 18s.—I had part of it in my pocket, and the other in my hand—I took out a sove
reign, to pay for some cold meat, and bread, and porter—I took in my hand what change I had got, and put it into my pocket—when I went in he saw me putting my hand into my pocket, he took hold of my hand, and took what I had in my hand, and what was in my pocket.

Q. But you have said before, that he asked what money you had got? A. Yes, about five minutes before I changed the sovereign he asked what money I had got—I was putting my hand again into my pocket—I had my pocket up, not to make a noise—I let it go willingly, because I thought he would not take what was in my pocket at the bottom, and he took it all—he had got the money from me before he assigned the reason that it was to pay for what was to happen in the church—he got it from me without that explanantion—it was against my consent—I only did not take steps to recover it because I believed at the time what he said.

Q. Did you not say on another occasion, that when he asked what money you had got, you said, "I have not much;" he asked you to let him see how much, and you took some of the money out, and was counting it? A. He asked five minutes before, had I much money—I said, "I must look sharp, I have not much money now, scarcely as much as will free us from the Church"—I was not counting it—I did not say I was counting it when he took it out of my hand—I was counting it at the bar, and I was looking at it to see if it was right—as I came from the bar I was putting it into my pocket, and he thrust his hand across, and took hold of it—I did not intend to part with my money to him when he took it, but he quieted me by telling me it would be spent in the Church—he took it without my consent.

MARGARET MALONE . I am the sister of Catherine Malone. I was at the public-house in Aldersgate-street with them—I was standing by the side of the table—the prisoner was sitting by my sister's side—he ate his breakfast—my sister had one knee on the top of the other—the prisoner put his hand in her pocket, took up the money, and put it in his own pocket—she made an attempt to take the money out of his hand—she got him by the two hands and tried to get it—he put it into his pocket, and said he should wear the breeches—I went with them to Lambeth—there was a church at the side of the street, and a public-house at the other side—he stopped the cab man at the public-house—we got out of the cab—he pointed and said, "That is the Church"—he went into the public-house and called for half-a-pint of rum—I followed him and brought him out by the body—the publican asked what out intention was—I said they were going to be married, and he said, "You have not many minutes to delay"—it was only ten minutes to twelve o'clock—the prisoner said, "Where is Kitty?—I said, "There she is"—he followed her up, and between her and me he ran away—he had got all my sister's money, and goods, and everything else—she had not a farthing left.

Cross-examined. Q. In the public-house did you not hear the prisoner whisper to her, and then take the money? A. No—he did not like her well enough to whisper—I never saw a young man that had such a dislike to a young woman in company—he did not whisper before he put his hand in her pocket—this is my mark to this deposition—(read—"On the day they were going to be married I went with them to the public-house in Alders
gate-street—the prisoner whispered to her, and then put his hand down to her pocket."
COURT. Q. Why do you tell us now that he did not whisper to her when you said before the Magistrate that he did whisper to her? A. Yes, his head was quite close to her ear—I did not hear it.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Now you recollect there was some whispering? A. Yes—I did not see my sister counting the money—I heard her say, "Let me have my money."

WILLIAM WREFORD (City police-constable No. 54.) I was called by Margaret Malone to a house in Red Lion-court, Fleet-street—I there re
ceived the prisoner in charge—I heard the prosecutrix ask him where the ring was—he said it was lost.
JONATHAN ROOTS . I am the parish clerk of Spitalfields. I register the banns of marriage at that Church—no banns have been put up between the prisoner and Catherine Malone.

----BIRKET. I register the banns of marriage at the parish Church of St. Giles, Cripplegate—no banns have been put up there for a marriage be
tween the prisoner and Catherine Malone.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know that? A. I have referred to the book, and have no such name for three months back.
JAMES MARTIN GOWRIE . I am parish clerk of St. Mary's, Lambeth. We have no register of the banns of the prisoner and Catherine Malone—we have no such names for the last three months.

CATHERINE SWAINE . I am a dress-maker. I was present at the public-house when these parties were going to be married—it was at the King's Arms, in Aldersgate-street—I saw some money pass between them—I sat directly opposite Catherine and John Clarke—I saw the prosecutrix count money into his hand—he sat on the left side of her—her pocket was on the right—I made her dress—I saw her take the money out of her pocket and count it into his hand—that was not many minutes before we left—we got up directly and proceeded to Lambeth—Catherine proposed having a cab, and two females sat inside.

COURT Q. What time did you get to the King's Arms? A. I think it must have been about eleven o'clock—they started from my house—when they got to the King's Arms they had a Knuckle of harm or bacon—Catherine went outside, and paid for what we had—when she came back she sat down, and the prisoner sat on the left-hand side of her—they were talking, but I was not close enough to hear their conversation—I was opposite them, but the table was between us, and it was lengthways—I saw her put her hand into her pocket, take out the money, and count it into his hand—I do not know what money she counted—her friend was sitting by my side, addressing herself to me, which took my attention—I saw her count it into his hand—I know there were half-crowns—I saw that—this was done voluntarily; in fact she was smiling the whole time—she never demanded it back—I believe the word did pass that he would wear the breeches—she made no effort to get the money back—she gave it him deliberately—he and her were talking at the bar afterwards, and I thought he had given her the money back—I do not know what he did with it—I did not see him put it into his pocket—we all got up—I heard Catherine say, "Come, John, we shall be too late."

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you see them speak? A. Yes—they were talk
ing the whole time after they has eaten—I did not hear them talk loud in a rational manner—Elizabeth Sperring was talking to me—I could not listen to both at once—Margaret Malone was standing in the middle of the floor—I did not feel much interest in their conversation.

ELIZABETH SPERRING . I was in the King's Arms, Aldersgate-street—we left Mr. Swaine's in Red Cross-street, and went there to wait for Mr. Swaine—the prisoner said he was rather hungry—Catherine went out to get some provision at the bar—she came in and sat down—it was a long table—the prisoner sat down opposite her, and eat up the refreshment—the bride sat opposite him, not by the side of him—after the refreshment Mr. Swaine came in—the prisoner got up, gave him his seat, and he went and sat on the left side of Catherine—Mr. Swaine and I were at the other end—Margaret Malone was standing up—I never saw any money, nor heard it—I never saw the money pass either way—the only word I heard was, "I shall wear the breeches"—I do not know on what subject the prisoner used those words—Mr. Swaine did not see what took place—when we got into the cab Catherine said, "He has got all my money"—I told it to Mr. Swaine—"Oh dear!" (she said) "has he got her money?"—she said it as if she were surprised, not as if she had seen it counted into his hand.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

858.
WILLIAM BROCKSOP and
GEORGE BENTLIFFE were indicted for
stealing 1 basket, value 2d.; 2lbs., weight of bread, 4d.; 1lb. weight of cheese, 7d.; and 1 fork, 6d.; the goods of
Thomas James; and that Bentliffe had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) I was in company with Cudley, another officer, between eight and nine o'clock on Saturday night, the 20th of Feb.—I saw the two prisoners in company together near the Ele
phant and Castle, looking into a stationer's shop—they then crossed near to the alms-house—they went up towards Kennington—they followed a wagon to the Goat's Head, in the Wandsworth-road—the wagon then stopped, and the prisoners stopped at the same time—I saw them for about a minute, and then lost sight of them—I remained there till the wagoner went on—I followed him for about 300 yards, and then saw the prisoners—they had changed their cap and hat—they followed the wagon to the Nag's Head, where it stopped—they turned back, and came to Vauxhall again—I and my brother officer ran after them for nearly a mile, till we came to the waterworks at Vauxhall—there Brocksop held up a basket, and Bentliffe was with him—we followed them to Kennington-cross, and there I stopped them—Brocksop wanted to know what it was for—I said, "For being about the road to commit felony"—I found part of a loaf and a bit of cheese in the basket, and when I took Brocksop he was eating bread and cheese—the man who was driving the wagon appeared the next day—he identified the basket and a fork that was in it—the prisoners had been following the wagon for about half an hour.

Brocksop. Q. Are you perfectly confident you saw us follow the wagon up Kennington-lane? A. Yes—I did not see the basket stolen from the wagon—I did not see you cross in front of the horses—when you ran you passed me on the opposite side of the road—I cannot say I saw you run, but I ran till I saw you.

WILLIAM ATLEE (police-constable L 110.) I was with Goff when we stopped the prisoners, eating bread and cheese—Brocksop had the basket—Bentliffe said it was his—I found the fork in Bentliffe's pocket, and a knife in his hand.
THOMAS BENT (police-constable V 95.) The prisoners were pointed out to me near the Goat's Head—I saw them change hat for cap—I could not run fast enough to catch them.

Brocksop. Q. Did you see us go near the wagon? A. Yes—I saw you cross the road in front of the horses—I did not see you with anything in your possession, it was too dark—I did not see you run—the horse patrol came up, and made you go off so fast.

THOMAS JAMES . I am a small farmer, and live at Broomshead, near Leap
hook. This is my basket, and this is my fork—they were in my wagon on the 20th of Feb.—I never missed the basket till I got to the Nag's Head—I had a quartern loaf and about three quarters of a pound of cheese in the bas
ket—it was in the fore part of the wagon, towards the horses—it could not have dropped out—it was up in the wagon—a cloth laid at the top of it—it laid on the floor of the wagon, quite safe.

Brocksop's Defence. I met Bentliffe at the Elephant and Castle; I had not known him more than a month; he said, "I am going to meet a friend will you go with me and meet him?" he said, "We will go up Kennington-lane;" we went as far as Wandsworth; and on returning, nearly opposite the waterworks, this basket laid in the road; I took it, and held it up to the light; there was bread and cheese in it; We commenced eating it, and were taken; I am not known to the police as having committed any offence, neither have I done so.

JAMES CUDDY (police-constable D 20.) I produce a certificate of Bent
liffe's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 24th Oct., 1842, having been before convicted of felony, transported for seven years)—I was present—he is the person.

BROCKSOP—
GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Judgment Respited.

BENTLIFFE—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

859.
GEORGE MOODY was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 waistcoat, 1l.; 1 pair of trowsers, 1l.; 1 watch, 4l.; 5 shirts 16s.; 1 pair of drawers, 3s.; 1 pair of stockings, 4s.; 1 pair of boots, 5s.; and 1 flannel shirt, 5s.; the goods of
Matthew Sharp, on board a vessel in the navigable river Thames; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

860.
JAMES HADDON and
WILLIAM BELL were indicted for
steal
ing 1 silk handkerchief, value 1s., of a certain man whose name is unknown, from his person; and that Haddon had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN BAKER (police-constable M 72.) On the evening of 26th Feb. I was on duty in Blackfriars-road—I saw the two prisoners together, trying the pockets of several persons—at last they came to a gentleman—Haddon got hold of his right hand pocket and extracted this handkerchief from it—Bell was walking by Haddon's side to conceal him from persons passing—Bell saw me, and he ran down a street—Haddon ran into the road, and threw down this handkerchief—I took it up, and secured him—I do not know who the gentleman was.
Bell. Q. How do you know me? A. From having seen you in custody at Southwark police-court in Oct. last—you had three months.
Haddon. I am not guilty of it; you take his bare word; I am innocent—the officer, Coombs, came to the cell, and said, "Plead guilty;" I said, "what should I plead guilty for, when I am innocent?"

WILLIAM COOMBS (police-constable L 94.) No—I saw him as we came by the cell, and he said, "Let my mother know"—I heard from Baker that Hadden was in custody. and that Bell ran away—I ascertained from two other
officers that Bell lodged at Burn's—I went there, and looked in the beds, but he was not there.

Bell. When this happened I was at home; Coombs saw me and this prisoner in a pudding-shop; I went home and slept there that night; it appears he went to this prisoner, and said, "Where can I find Bell, is he at Burn's?" he said he did not know; he went to Burn's and looked over the beds, and could not find me; I was coming down the cut on the Satur
day, and a man who was a constable, but lost his coat through some misdeed, took me picking pockets; he took me to the station; and this policeman before he saw me, said "That is him;" I was inside, and he was outside the doorway; he came in, and said, "That is him."
COURT to JOHN BAKER. Q. At what time was it you saw the prisoners? A. Shortly after seven o'clock in the evening—it was a few minutes after eight when I took Haddon—I am sure Bell was with him.

CATHERINE DENSON . I live in pearl-raw, Blackfriars-road—I know Bell—on Friday week he came home between eight and nine in the evening, as near as possible—he remained there all night—if he got out of bed again it was more than I knew.
(The certificate of Haddon's previous conviction was for a misdemeanor only.)

HADDON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BELL—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

861.
JOHN TRIGG was indicted
for stealing 1 pickaxe, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Watts Palmer and
George Wood.—2nd COUNT, of the Surveyors of the Highway of the parish of Wandsworth, in Surrey.

JAMES SWINDLEY (police-constable V 308.) on Monday, 1st march, I saw the prisoner in High-street, Wandsworth, with this pickaxe on his shoulder—I asked where he got it—he said he picked it up on the Green, opposite the Union work house.

JOHN MORGAN WALL . I live at Wandsworth, and am employed by the surveyors of the highway of the parish—one of them is named Thomas Palmer, and the other George Wood—I know this pickaxe—I worked with it for seven years—it belonged to the surveyors of the highway of the parish—the name is on it—I was at work with it last Saturday week, in the morn
ing and put it by the side of the road, near the railway bridge—when we were coming away, about five o'clock, I missed it—I know nothing of the prisoner.

JOSEPH MEARS . I am a brickmaker, and live at Somer's-town—the pri
soner was in my field for about half an hour on the 27th Feb, between two and three o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Month.

862.
ANN CUNNIMGHAM was indicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 1s. 8 sovereigns, 4 half-sovereigns, and 2 5l. Bank-notes; the property of
Jeremiah O'Connor, from his person;
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
for feloniously receiving, harbouring, and maintaining her, knowing her to have committed the said felony; and that Williams had been before convicted of felony.

JEREMIAH O'CONNOR . I keep the Grapes' public-house, in White-street; Southwark—I know the prisoner Cunningham—I had seen her several time at my house—I knew her by sight, not by name—on Friday, 19th Feb; I had been to Rotherhithe—I was returning home about eleven o'clock at night
