or it might be later—I had been drinking—the liquor took effect on my head, but I knew perfectly well what I was about—I remember being in Milpond-street—up to that time I had been in company with Mr. Bryan, whom I have known many years—I went to a doctor's shop to purchase a plaster to cure corns—I put it into my pocket in a paper—I had two 5l. Bank-notes, and 10l. in gold, in a purse in my right hand trowsers pocket—there were sovereigns and half-sovereigns—I had some silver in my other pocket—I felt my purse safe when I was in the doctor's shop, in Milpond-street—after I parted with Mr. Bryan I came straight along Milpond-street, in a direction towards my own house—as I was coming along I had to pass the end of a road or street—I think it is called the Neckinger—there is a public-house very convenient to it, called Lillyput-hall—at the corner of the street I saw two women and a man standing still—I passed them, and as I passed I heard a women's voice say, "There is Connor, from the Brought"—I walked on towards the railway—I heard a women run after me—she came up to me, and got hold of my arm—it was the prisoner, cun
ningham—she said, "Are you not going to stand something to drink?"—I said, "No," or something to that effect—we walked on about twenty yards, and got to a railway arch—we went round the arch up out of sight—she began to handle me, and she had an opportunity of putting her hand into my pocket—she did not say anything, but ran away with great swiftness—I missed my purse, and ran after her, and called, "stop thief"—I fell down, and my hat fell off—I left my hat, and ran after her—I did not go far before a man came up, and said, "Connor, did she rob you of your money?"—I said, "Yes"—that man came in a direction from Lilliput-hall, where I had seen a man and two women—to the best of my belief, that man was the prisoner, Williams—he seized my gold guard-chain, but my waistcoat being tight he did not succeed in getting it—the chain broke—I said, "you villain, do you mean to rob me of my watch?" and I hit him in the mouth=Bryan came up imme
diately, and he said to me, "Don't strike the man, Connor"—I said, "why, he intended to rob me of my watch"—Bryan said, "You villain, did you mean to rob the man?" and took hold of him—I said, "keep him till I sing out 'Police!'"—I went singing out "police!" as loud as I could—we could not find one directly—in the course of some time after I saw Bryan again—I said, "You do not mean to say you have let the prisoner go?"—he said yes, he was obliged to let him go—I afterwards saw a constable, and gave him informa
tion—he said, "I know who it is"—I know I had my purse when I went up the archway, and it was gone when the women was running away—there was nobody that could have taken it but her—I gave a description of the purse and money—I said there was a small half-sovereign of William the Fourth's reign—you may have 100l. in gold, and not have one like that.

Cross-examined by MR. BRIERLY. Q. What do they call you? A. My name is Jeremiah O'Connor, but I answer to the name of Connor—I have "O'Connor" over my door, and that is what I write in a letter—this was not a club night—I had been drinking, but I knew perfectly well what I was about—I went to see a publican, a coutryman of mine, and a person who was foreman over Bryan—we three had two glasses of gin and water for three of us—that might be about nine o'clock—I had no dinner that day—I had tea at home—after Bryan and I came from the house I had a glass and a half of ale, and I had part of three glasses of gin and water—that was all I drank from the time I felt there till I left Bryan—that took more effect on me than if I had bad a dinner—my head will not bear so much as others do—the robbery was committed between eleven and twelve—when I passed the two

women and the man I did not know who they were—I was not gone above ten yards when I heard a woman say," There is Connor from the Borough"—I saw a man at the corner, but I could not identify Williams as being the man I passed—when we were under the arches it was rather dark—I cannot tell whether there was any moon that night—there was plenty of gas about—when the man came up to me and said, "Has she robbed you of your money?" I said "Yes"—I thought it was some kind person who heard I had been robbed, and no sooner had he said that then he made a grasp at my guard, and I hit him in the mouth—to the best of my belief it was the prisoner Williams, but I will not swear to it—I would not swear to him in the morning, but by the appearance, and his having a cut in the mouth—I said, "Who gave you that cut in you mouth?"—he said, "I have had it some time"—I said, "I have got you old chap "—I did not see what sort of mark I had put upon him—I had not spoken to any one before this women came up to me—from the time I shook hands with my friends, no one stopped me or spoke to me—the policeman has the watch and guard.

CHARLES BRYAN. I live in Rotherhithe—I know Mr. O'Connor. On Friday, 19th Feb., I was in his company part of the evening—I did not think he was the worse for what he had taken—he was able to walk and talk—I offered to see him home—I was coming home with him, and he said, "Bryan you are coming too far"—I was coming home with him because I knew he had money and a watch about him—I saw the chain on his neck—after leaving him, I watched him—I kept him in sight, and saw him going along the road—I saw to females and a man, at the corner of Neckinger-road, near Lilliput-hall—he passed them quietly—I was crossing the road, and I beard one woman say to the other woman," There is Connor from the Borough," and the other woman left and went after him—I turned my face and saw the woman who said the words, and I knew her face—I saw the woman who went after Connor take hold of his arm, or put her hand under his arm, I could not see which—they crossed to go under the arches, I there lost sight of them—I did not know whether they went under the railroad, or alongside of it—I walked along, looking for them, and I heard Connor sing out for a policeman—I knew his voice—I ran towards him and asked what was the matter—he said he had been robbed of 20l.—he had not his hat on—I looked after his hat, and I saw the prisoner Williams come up to him—I had known Williams before by sight—he put his hand in a rough manner on Connor's breast, and said, "Have you been robbed of 20l."—Williams's back was towards me, and I heard Connor say, "You villain, you want to draw my watch"—Connor hit him—I went up and said, "Do not hit him"—Connor said, "He wanted to rob me of my watch," and I laid hold of him—he said, "Let me go, let me go; what business have you with me?"—I said, "Stand till the policeman comes"—he stopped down, and his coat was coming over his head—I thought he would get away—I made a second grab at him, he slipped away and ran off—I ran after him singing "Police!"—I came against a post, and it hit me so that I felt the blow for a week afterwards—I knew Williams before, and to the best of my belief he was the person who was with the two women.

Cross-examined. Q. How came you to know Williams? A. I cannot say—I have been twenty years in the Borough—I have seen him as I was coming home from my work, and know him right well—it would take about three minutes to walk to the arch from where the two women and the man were standing—I did not see the woman run away from Connor—She went on one side of the arch and I on the other—I did not meet her, or I would have collared her directly after the cry out that he had been robbed—I do not suppose it was two minutes be
fore Williams was up—I had had a pint of beer, and my part of five glasses of

gin and water between Connor and me and the landlord—I knew the other woman, who was at the corner, by having seen her so many times—the gas-light was very strong—there was none under the arch—I followed Connor because I thought I would see him part of the way home—I was nearer to my home than he was, and it is the way of my country people to convey a friend home, to show him respect—I did not take notice of his being tipsy, only merry—he was able to take care of himself—I may have said he was the worse for liquor; I dare say I did—I did not notice that he was in any way drunk.
MR. PAYNE. Q. You say he was merry, but knew what he was about? A. Yes.

JOHN UTLEY . I am a publican, and live in Eaton-place, Kent-street. On Friday night, the 19th of Feb., about a quarter-past eleven o'clock, I saw Cunningham at my house—she had a quartern of the best rum, and paid for it with a half-sovereign—after I had given her the change she asked if I would have the goodness to take care of 2l. 10s. for her till the morning, as she was afraid she should lose it—she produced three half-sovereigns and a good one—I did not notice of what reign it was—it was very small—I have seen one as small before, and never but one—I put the money on the shelf behind, and kept it for her—she did not come for it, and I took it to the Police-court, as I thought it had been stolen—I afterwards came to Newgate to see Cunningham—she was the woman that left the money with me—after she had left this 2l. 10s. with me to keep for her, she went out, and returned in about five minutes, and the prisoner. Williams was with her—they whis
pered together for a long time—I could not hear much that they said, they watched me too well, but I heard Williams distinctly say, "I don't think he will know me again" I think they had a pot of beer, and went away about a quarter before twelve o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen either of them before? A. I had seen Williams many times—I knew him well—I do not think that I had seen Cunningham.

GEORGE RADFORD (police-sergeant M 19.) In consequence of informa
tion, I went at half-past one o'clock in the night of the 19th of Feb., to No. 55, Ann-street, Henry-street, kent-road, and found Cunningham in bed with Williams—I commenced searching the bed—Canningham said I need not search, I should find nothing—Williams asked if I was going to take his girl from him—he had given her 2s. to sleep with him for the night—he said he met her in White-street, and they went into the Grapes, and had a quartern of gin together—I took Cunningham to the station—I said it was on suspi
cion of robbing a publican—she said she had not robbed any person, that she had left the railway about half-past ten o'clock—she said Williams had given her 2s., that she picked him up in White-street, and she would not have taken him home for 2s. if she had had any money—I did not know anything about a charge against Williams at that time—when I took Cunningham, Williams went away—between that time and half-past four. I received some informa
tion about Williams—I went to the same house I had taken Cunningham from—I found the room door shut, and a chair propped against it to prevent its opening—I got in at the window, and found Williams lying on the bed with his clothes on—he pretended to be asleep—we shook him, and got him into the yard, and told him we wanted him for being concerned in the robbery of 20l.—we got him to the station, and told him it was on suspicion of attempt
tempting
to steal a watch—he said, "Oh, if it is only on suspicion, that will do."

THOMAS WILLIAM REDFORD (police-constable L 52.) I produce a certifi
cate of Williams's former conviction at Newington Sessions—(read—Con
victed on the 5th of Dec., 1842, and transported for seven years)—I was present—he is the person.
Cross-examined. Q. That is a long while ago? A. Yes—I have not seen him since that time—I had known him before for a long period—he had been convicted before that twenty-five times.

CUNNINGHAM—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 21

864.
JOHN SLAUSON was indicted
for stealing 2 loaves of bread, value 1s. 4d., the goods of
James Godwin, master of
George Walker; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Weeks.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 5TH OF APRIL, 1847.
